title: The Adventure of the Clapham Cook
episodeSummary: Poirot takes a humble case involving a missing domestic, one which leads to uncovering a crime much more sinister.

crimes.motive: Put suspicion on another person at the bank.
crimes.opportunity: Lunch at his lodgings on Weds with Davis

crimes.means: Diverting suspicion to Simpson and stealing them himself
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Simpson had regular access to the securities as a bank employee

crimes.means: Posing as an Australian barrister with false inheritance documents.
crimes.motive: Getting Eliza out of the way to use her trunk to conceal a body
crimes.opportunity: Simpson had the day off sick

title: Murder in the Mews
episodeSummary: Poirot's investigation of a victim's life leads him to ask if she was right- or left-handed.  The answer will determine whether the case is one of murder or suicide.

crimes.means: Framing an innocent man of murder
crimes.motive: Revenge
crimes.opportunity: Placing incriminating evidence in Mrs. Allen's room which pointed to Major Eustace and made it seem like he was lying about the details of his visit

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: He learned about the victim's past when they were both living in India.

title: The Adventure of Johnnie Waverly
episodeSummary: Poirot is engaged to prevent the kidnapping of a country squire's son.

crimes.means: Cooperation with others inside the household
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Sneaking the child out with the nurse while everyone was distracted by the commotion in the front

title: Four and Twenty Blackbirds
episodeSummary: Poirot and his dentist dine at a restarant and witness a reclusive painter enjoying his last meal.  Poirot's investigation of the murder focuses on why he changed his eating habits.

crimes.means: Throwing the victim down the stairs
crimes.motive: Inherit the deceased's fortune
crimes.opportunity: Visiting the old man and disguising the time of death

title: The Third Floor Flat
episodeSummary: Poirot returns from seeing a play to find that the new tennant at Whitehaven Mansions has been murdered.

crimes.motive: Release from marriage when his wife would not grant a divorce so he can marry another woman
crimes.opportunity: Visiting her apartmet during the day before going to the play

title: Triangle at Rhodes
episodeSummary: Poirot tries to relax on holiday in Rhodes, keeping a watchful eye on the love-triangle brewing towards murder.

crimes.motive: Release from marriage and inherit his wife's fortune
crimes.opportunity: He poisoned the drink the Douglas Gold gave him in order to incriminate Gold

crimes.motive: Divert suspicion away from the real murder suspects
crimes.opportunity: Poisoning the pink gin that Gold had just given him and giving it to his wife

title: Problem at Sea
episodeSummary: When the dislikable fellow passenger Mrs. Clapperton is murdered, Poirot and Hastings investigate during their holiday cruise.

crimes.motive: Release from marriage to his wife who he hated
crimes.opportunity: Using ventriloquism to disguise the time of death and secure an alibi

title: The Incredible Theft
episodeSummary: Poirot is drawn into international political intrigue when the plans for a new combat aircraft are stolen by a German spy.

crimes.means: Taking the engineering plans left out on Mayfield's desk
crimes.motive: Nationalism
crimes.opportunity: Mayfield intentionally left the plans out for her to steal as a trap

crimes.means: A letter proving that Mayfield sold artillary to the Japanese during an arms embargo
crimes.motive: Gain leverage over Mayfield to gain access to military secrets
Greed
crimes.opportunity: Contacts with the Japanese buyers

title: The King of Clubs
episodeSummary: Poirot is called in to help when a young actress is caught up in the murder of the head of the studio.

crimes.means: Knowledge of the Oglander's previous identities and past
crimes.motive: Gain power and leverage over the young actress
crimes.opportunity: Research of past newspapers

crimes.means: Fist and blunt trauma to the back of the head
crimes.motive: Protect his sister
crimes.opportunity: During an argument at Reedburn's home office.

title: The Dream
episodeSummary: A wealthy industrialist invites Poirot to a meeting and describes a dream where he shoots himself, then dies the next day under similar circumstances.

crimes.motive: Jealousy and greed.  Killing Farley would allow him to marry the widow Farley and gain Farley's wealth
crimes.opportunity: Knowing the victim's habit of sticking his head out the window to check for steam coming from the oven chimneys

title: Peril at End House
episodeSummary: While on holiday, Poirot meets a young woman who has narrowly escaped three deadly accidents.  When he discovers a bullet hole in her hat, he vows to prevent her murder.

crimes.motive: Greed.  Inherit a fortune
crimes.opportunity: Access to an old copy of a real will that Nick Buckley wrote and they witnessed

crimes.means: Nick's real name is also Magdala, and she stole the love letters from Matthew Seton that were originally addresses to her cousin of the same name
crimes.motive: Greed.  Inherit the fortune left to her cousin in Matthew Seton's will
crimes.opportunity: Inviting her cousin to stay at End House periodically

crimes.motive: Get her cousin out of the way and assume her identity
crimes.opportunity: A few moments alone with her cousin while heading to the house, and using the popping sounds of the fireworks to disguise the shot

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Maritime background and frequent outings on the water

title: The Veiled Lady
episodeSummary: Poirot becomes a cat burglar to recover a letter being used for blackmail and becomes entwined in a jewel-theft case.

crimes.means: Pistol and then handing the stolen goods to Lavington during a false citizen's arrest
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Inside information about the inventory from a blackmailer, and then hitting the jewelery shop during business hours

crimes.motive: Recover the letter being used to blackmail Lady Millicent
crimes.opportunity: Posing as a tradesman and installing compromised security and locks

crimes.motive: Get Lavington out of the way and steal back the jewels
crimes.opportunity: Lavington's holiday in Holland
crimes.perpetrator: Gertie and Joey Weatherly's associates in Holland

title: The Lost Mine
episodeSummary: When a man carrying a map to a lost silver mine is found murdered in Chinatown, the trail leads Poirot to London's underground opium dens.

crimes.motive: Stealing the map in his posession
crimes.opportunity: Meeting Wu Ling at the port when he arrived from China

crimes.criminalAct: Theft of the map to the lost silver mine
crimes.means: Killing Wu Lin and taking it
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Meeting Wu Ling at the port when he arrived from China

crimes.motive: To throw the police off the trail of the real murder
crimes.opportunity: Posing as Wu Ling and planting evidence in the victim's hotel room, and then drugging the victim and leaving him at the crime scene.

title: The Cornish Mystery
episodeSummary: A woman confides to Poirot that she fears her husband is poisoning her.  Poirot acts too late to prevent tragedy and then investigates her murder, as the inquest puts her husband on trial.

crimes.motive: Getting both parents out of the way so his wife would inherit their fortune
crimes.opportunity: Access to the victim's meals

crimes.criminalAct: Conspiracy, perjury, and obstruction of justice
crimes.motive: Getting both parents out of the way so his wife would inherit their fortune
crimes.opportunity: Testifying in court that he saw Pengelley with rat poison in hand when preparing his wife's meal

title: The Disappearance of Mr. Davenheim
episodeSummary: When a wealthy banker disappears, Poirot bets Japp that he can solve the case without leaving his flat.

crimes.means: Converting the funds into jewels and gems
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Access to bank funds

crimes.criminalAct: Obstruction of justice and making false statements to police
crimes.motive: Frame Gerald Lowen for murder
crimes.opportunity: Posing as Billy Kellet and singling out Lowen in a lineup

title: Double Sin
episodeSummary: When a young woman's delivery of antique miniatures is stolen, Hastings takes the case while Poirot sits back and ponders retirement.

crimes.criminalAct: Fraud and making false statements to police
crimes.means: Disguising herself and selling the miniatures to Kane but then using Mary's trip to claim they were stolen
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Mary's trip to see the client and a train ride to meet the client herself

title: The Adventure of the Cheap Flat
episodeSummary: Poirot and Japp help an FBI agent track a Mafia member carrying stolen, secret Navy plans, and a young couple's rental of a cheap flat draws them into the intrigue

crimes.motive: In love with Carla Romero
crimes.opportunity: As a clerk he had internal access to Navy documents
crimes.victim: United States Department of the Navy

crimes.motive: Steal the stolen Navy documents
crimes.opportunity: Setting a fake meeting with a buyer for the documents which was a trap

crimes.means: Loosening the screw on the bolt for the rear-access garbage bin doors
crimes.motive: Stop the assassin targeting the Robinsons
crimes.opportunity: Distracting the couple and reinstalling the loose bolt latch.

crimes.motive: Assassinate the Robinsons
crimes.opportunity: Waiting until night and breaking in.

title: The Kidnapped Prime Minister
episodeSummary: The Prime Minister is kidnapped en route to a vital meeting at the League of Nations.  The trail leads to France, but Poirot refuses to go, convinced the answer to the case is on the English side of the Channel.

crimes.motive: Allow Germany to rearm and weaken Britain's position, securing independence for Ireland
crimes.opportunity: Inside co-conspirator as the Prime Minister's assistant

crimes.means: Faking the kidnapping location in France and throwing the investigation off the trail
crimes.motive: Abetting the conspiracy to keep the Prime Minister away from the League of Nations meeting
crimes.opportunity: Inside co-conspirator as the Prime Minister's assistant

title: The Adventure of the Western Star
episodeSummary: Poirot investigates when two fabulous diamonds, the Eastern and Western Star, are stolen.

crimes.motive: Greed and desire to possess the Eastern Star diamond
crimes.opportunity: An indiscreet relationship between the two of them

crimes.criminalAct: Making false statements to police and Insurance Fraud
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Disguising himself as a Chinaman and staging the theft

crimes.means: Acting as broker in a stolen property deal
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Connecting the two clients in the deal

title: The Mysterious Affair at Styles
episodeSummary: Hastings recuperates from a war injury at Styles and happens to meet up with Poirot, who has settled there as a refugee.  When the lady of the house is murdered, Hastings asks Poirot for help with the case.

crimes.motive: Greed.  Inherit the fortune of the deceased
crimes.opportunity: Putting the sleeping poweders into the sleeping draft, and the bromide precipitated the strychnine to the bottom in a final, fatal dose

title: How Does Your Garden Grow?
episodeSummary: At a flower show where a rose is being named after him, Poirot receives a mysterious, empty seed-packet from an elderly woman.  After discovering he has received a letter from the same woman, Poirot decides to visit her home, only to find that she has been murdered.

crimes.motive: Greed.  Inherit.
crimes.opportunity: Adding the poison to her favourite food, oysters

crimes.means: Forging letters to Barrowby's accountant to move into high risk stock
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Access to the victim's real hand-written letters for copying

title: The Million Dollar Bond Robbery
episodeSummary: One million dollars in Liberty Bonds are stolen when Poirot and Hastings board the H.M.S. Queen Mary to accompany delivery of the bonds to New York.

crimes.means: Stealing the bonds before the voyage
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Possession of one of the keys to the portmanteau and putting fake bonds into it

crimes.means: Framing an innocent man for the crime
crimes.motive: Divert suspicion away from the real theft
crimes.opportunity: Stealing the real bonds before the voyage and dropping the fake bonds into the ocean after getting Ridgeway to take the place of Shaw after 2 fake murder attempts

title: The Plymouth Express
episodeSummary: An Australian businessman convinces Poirot to investigate the suitor courting his daughter, but the background investigation turns into an intrigue-filled murder case.

crimes.motive: Steal Florence Carrington's jewels
crimes.opportunity: She was traveling alone and he went to her compartment as the train neared Bristol

crimes.means: Impersonating the victim so that the time of death would be
crimes.motive: Steal Florence Carrington's jewels
crimes.opportunity: Wearing the same clothes as the victim and riding on the train with her ready to take her place after the murder

crimes.means: Spreading rumors about the Yellow Creek Mining company that a geologist report would be unfavourable
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Bringing £20,000 in bearer bonds to England as security to buy shares at the low price and sell them when the real report came out

title: Wasps' Nest
episodeSummary: Poirot tries to prevent a murder after he sees clues to a plot forming at a garden party.

crimes.motive: Revenge
crimes.opportunity: Commiting suicide with poison in his own tea after having Langton over to kill wasps with the same poison

title: The Tragedy at Marsdon Manor
episodeSummary: When advising a murder-mystery author who has written himself into a corner, a real murder occurs in a nearby manor, and Poirot is called to investigate.

crimes.motive: Greed.  Collect on the life insurance policy of her husband
crimes.opportunity: Using her husband's poor health and the superstitious fright of the local legend, knowing it would be unlikely that the coroner would find the tiny wound from the rook rifle

title: The Double Clue
episodeSummary: Poirot tracks a high-profile jewel thief and becomes enchanted with the beautiful Russian Countess Vera Rossakoff.

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Sneaking away from the performance during the party

title: The Mystery of the Spanish Chest
episodeSummary: A jealous husband is found murdered inside a Spanish chest after a party, and the beautiful widow becomes the prime suspect.

crimes.motive: Jealousy.  To removal all potential rivals for Marguerite Clayton's affection
crimes.opportunity: Convince Clayton to hide in the chest during the party to spy on his wife and then stab him through the eye with the stiletto

crimes.means: Frame Major Rich for the murder
crimes.motive: Jealousy.  To remove all potential rivals for Marguerite Clayton's affection
crimes.opportunity: Convince Clayton to hide in the chest curing the party to spy on his wife and then stab him through the eye with the stiletto

title: The Theft of the Royal Ruby
episodeSummary: An Egyptian Prince's ruby is stolen, and Poirot secretly tracks the thief while on Christmas holiday.

crimes.means: Deceiving the Prince and stealing the jewel
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Posing as a date for the Prince

title: The Affair at the Victory Ball
episodeSummary: A pall is cast over the Victory Ball when two of the costumed revelers wind up dead, but Poirot unmasks the murderer.

crimes.motive: Avoid being exposed as a drug trafficker
crimes.opportunity: Giving her the dose on the taxi ride to her home

crimes.motive: Avoid being exposed as a drug trafficker
crimes.opportunity: A moment alone with Cronshaw during the party

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Contacts with customers

title: The Mystery of Hunter's Lodge
episodeSummary: Poirot and Hastings attend a grouse-shooting, only to be drawn into an investigation when their host is murdered later that night.

crimes.motive: Inherit
crimes.opportunity: Pose a Mrs Middleton and commit the crime, putting suspicion on a non-existant person

crimes.means: Have Zoe Havering get off the train midway and return to the lodge by bicycle to commit the murder
crimes.motive: Inherit
crimes.opportunity: Board the train to London to secure his alibi

title: The ABC Murders
episodeSummary: A serial killer who chooses his victims alphabetically taunts Poirot with letters detailing his next murder, always leaving a copy of the ABC Railway Guide at each scene.

crimes.motive: Draw attention away from the one murder with a real motive
crimes.opportunity: Asking for cigarettes and striking while her back was turned

crimes.motive: Draw attention away from the one murder with a real motive
crimes.opportunity: Following the woman along the beach

crimes.motive: Inherit and prevent his brother from marrying Thora Grey after his wife died.
crimes.opportunity: Following his brother on his walk and striking him while his back was turned

crimes.motive: Draw attention away from the one murder with a real motive
crimes.opportunity: Stab the man while at the cinema

crimes.motive: Draw attention away from the one murder with a real motive
crimes.opportunity: Hire Cust as a stockings salesman to go to the places and visit possible clients where the murders would be committed, and writing letters to Poirot about the intention to commit murder

title: Death in the Clouds
episodeSummary: Poirot travels to Paris to see a tennis championship, and on the return flight a passenger is murdered with a poison dart.

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Posing as the steward while most of the passengers were sleeping and pressing the dart into her neck

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: A train ride together with his new wife

title: One, Two, Buckle My Shoe
episodeSummary: Poirot's dentist apparently commits suicide in the middle of the day between apointments, and Poirot unravels the mystery.

crimes.motive: Assume the identity of the dentist to murder his next patient
crimes.opportunity: Waiting until after his dental treatment completed and then shooting him

crimes.means: Poison.  A shot of novacaine and adrenaline
crimes.motive: Silencing the blackmailer
crimes.opportunity: Assuming Dr Morley's identity and administering the shot as part of the dental treatment

crimes.motive: Assuming the victim's identity and silencing her knowledge of Blunt's earlier marriage
crimes.opportunity: Inviting her over for tea

crimes.means: Getting married to Rebecca Arnholt while still being married to Gerda Grant
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Keeping the marriage secret among only a few who knew it in India

crimes.means: Firing a shot at Blunt and throwing the gun near his feet
crimes.motive: Frame the victim for murder
crimes.opportunity: Hiring the victim as a gardener under the guise of a secret service contract

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Learning of the information from Mabelle Sainsbury-Seale

title: The Adventure of the Egyptian Tomb
episodeSummary: Poirot travels to Egypt to investigate a series of four explorers' mysterious deaths after opening a Pharaoh's tomb in the Valley of the Kings.

crimes.motive: To get the fortune to pass to Rupert Bleibner
crimes.opportunity: Role as doctor for the archeological dig

crimes.means: Falsely diagnosing leprosy to drive the victim to suicide

crimes.motive: To continue the myth of the curse of King Men-her-Ra

title: The Underdog
episodeSummary: Poirot attends dinner at a wealthy industrialist's house so he can view the host's collection of bronze miniatures, and that evening their host is murdered.

crimes.motive: Prevent the astroprene compound from being manufactuered at another company so he would benefit from the patent
crimes.opportunity: Hiding in the office alcove after dinner

title: The Yellow Iris
episodeSummary: When attending the opening of a new restarant, the circumstances and participants remind Poirot of an old, unsolved case.

crimes.means: Poison.  Potassium cyanide in the cocktail
crimes.motive: Silence her about the deal struck with the rebels
crimes.opportunity: Going around the table disguised as a waiter

crimes.means: Poison. Potassium cyanide in the cocktail
crimes.motive: Prevent her from discovering the embezzlement of the trust
crimes.opportunity: Going around the table disguised as a waiter

crimes.means: Bribing the rebel General with funds from the British government meant for the oil concessions

crimes.means: Control of the trust set aside for Pauline Wetherby
crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Control of the trust set aside for Pauline Wetherby

title: The Case of the Missing Will
episodeSummary: A terminally ill man asks Poirot to be executor for a new will that entrusts his entire estate to his female ward, but that night before he can author the new document, the sick man is murdered and the old will goes missing.

crimes.motive: Prevent Andrew Marsh from changing his will or revealing his real heir so that the inheritance would go to her son
crimes.opportunity: Luring him to the folly in the middle of the night

crimes.means: Planting evidence of insulin from Dr Pritchard's lab

title: The Adventure of the Italian Nobleman
episodeSummary: An Italian count is murdered at a table set for three in a tale of blackmail and coverup.

crimes.means: Letters proving support of anti-fascist groups in Italy
crimes.motive: Greed

crimes.motive: Greed
crimes.opportunity: Staging the murder scene details and lying to police about who was there

episodeSummary: Poirot travels with Japp to Brussels, where Japp receives an award from the Belgian government. While in Belgium, Poirot solves a cold case of a murdered politician.

crimes.motive: Religion

crimes.motive: Search the home for evidence of the poison

title: Dead Man's Mirror
episodeSummary: Poirot loses a bid for an antique mirror at an auction, only to have the winner ask him to dinner to investigate a case of fraud.  The party ends early when the host is shot before dinner.

crimes.motive: Prevent her biological daughter from being disinherited by Gervase's new will
crimes.opportunity: Sneaking into the study

crimes.motive: Get rid of the evidence

crimes.means: Setting up a front company and absconding with the funding

title: Jewel Robbery at the Grand Metropolitan
episodeSummary: Hastings joins Poirot when he takes a holiday for his health.  They go to see a new play, whose leading actress wears a priceless pearl necklace, which later goes missing.

crimes.means: Quickly removing the box from the room, opening it with a duplicate key and putting it back
crimes.motive: Greed.  Sell the necklace in America.

title: Hercule Poirot's Christmas
episodeSummary: Poirot's quiet Christmas plans are spoiled when the boiler at Whitehaven Mansions breaks down, but after receing an invite to an estate with central heating, he spends Christmas with a wealthy, old miser who is then murdered during the family's reunion,

crimes.motive: Revenge

crimes.opportunity: Visiting the victim for a donation to the holiday charity

episodeSummary: Miss Lemon asks Poirot to investigate a series of seemingly-unrelated thefts at a student hostel, a trail which leads to several desperate and daring murders.

crimes.motive: Make sure the hallway was darkened so as not to be seen

crimes.opportunity: Access to the hostel supply room

crimes.opportunity: Accessing her room before bedtime

crimes.motive: Love
crimes.opportunity: Unspecified

crimes.motive: Love.  Protect Jack Renauld

episodeSummary: Poirot and Hastings attend a speedboat world-record attempt.  When their hostess confides in Poirot her fear of being murdered, he suggests that she write a new will.  When she is killed anyway, Poirot looks to an unlikely witness.
